ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned many important statistical concepts, how to conduct and interpret statistical hypothesis tests, how to use Python and Juypiter notebooks to run tests and create visuals. Simultaneously, we were shown many examples of how statistics and data are presented in the media -- examples of how this has been done responsibly and when it has lacked context or proper interpretation.

Basic statistics (Confidence intervals, p-value, hypothesis testing, margin of error, etc), How statistics are used in media, how to read and interpret statistical results in journal papers and news media, and using python for statistical analysis

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was strong in that all the lectures were very well prepared -- there were lots and lots of media examples which was helpful. Personally, I would have liked to see more use of coding throughout the semester since we were taught it during every lecture and only really used it in the final project. I also thought given the small size of the class, more discussion could have been possible.

The class lectures have a lot of content and have very interesting examples from the news articles, videos, and journal articles. If you are taking the YData class along with it, lots of topics will overlap. Some of the homeworks are quite difficult and annoying as they require you to find examples in media and journal articles of certain statistical methods, which can be hard to find. The Homeworks are quite easy if you pay attention in class and reach out for help. Professor Donoghue is quite a fair grader and you will get a good grade if you put in the effort.

The strength of this course is the manageable workload. The weakness is that lectures focused too much on looking at media examples that were also covered in the textbook  I wish we spent more time actually covering the statistical background. I also wish we'd looked at more complex research examples  I feel like I only know how to interpret very basic analyses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom didn't really inhibit any aspects of the course since it was so coding and visual based.
The lectures were too long for the virtual format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would if you want to sediment your understanding of stat concepts that are at a fairly basic level -- if you've already taken 1+ 100 level stat class there's going to be a fair amount of repetition. However, you do a lot of it through a media lens, which is great if you're interested in the media or journalism. Also, the professor makes sure to ensure that students understand stats concepts on a real theoretical level and not just a computational level which is very useful.

Yes, it fairly easy if you are taking YData or already have knowledge of basic statistics. There really isn't anything too challenging if you understand the statistics. However, the lectures do have interesting examples and have good structure.
Not really, I don't think this course would teach you anything you wouldn't also learn in the main intro stats courses.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

extras.title:
S&DS 574 01/PLSC 539 01/S&DS 174 01/PLSC 440 01
        YData: Statistics in the Media
